scientificName: Cucurbita pepo, Cucurbita maxima, Cucurbita moschata
description: A cultivar of winter squash that is round with smooth, slightly ribbed skin, and is most often deep yellow to orange in coloration. The thick shell contains the seeds and pulp.
origin: North America (northeastern Mexico and southern United States)
healthBenefits: Excellent source of beta-carotene (Vitamin A), crucial for vision and immune health.
Rich in antioxidants that protect against chronic diseases.
Good source of fiber, aiding digestion and promoting fullness.
Contains potassium, which can help regulate blood pressure.

potentialAllergies.name: Cucurbit Allergy
potentialAllergies.details: Allergies to pumpkin are uncommon, but cross-reactivity can occur in individuals allergic to other gourds.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Planting: Warm-season crop. Sow seeds directly after last frost or start indoors.
2. Soil: Well-drained, fertile soil rich in organic matter. pH 6.0-6.8. Full sun.
3. Spacing: Vines need ample space to spread. Plant in hills or rows.
4. Watering: Requires consistent and deep watering, especially during fruit development.
5. Harvesting: Harvest when pumpkins are fully colored, rind is hard, and stem begins to dry. Cut from vine leaving a few inches of stem attached for better storage.
sustainabilityTips: Store whole pumpkins in a cool, dry place for several months.
Cooked pumpkin puree can be frozen for later use in pies, soups, or breads.
Roast pumpkin seeds for a nutritious snack.
Use pumpkin flesh in both sweet (pies, muffins) and savory (soups, curries) dishes.
carbonFootprintInfo: Generally low to moderate (0.3-0.7 kg CO2e/kg), especially if field-grown and consumed locally.

staticRecipes.name: Classic Pumpkin Pie
staticRecipes.description: A traditional autumn dessert with a spiced pumpkin custard filling in a flaky pie crust.
steps: Preheat oven to 425°F (220°C).
In a large bowl, whisk together pumpkin puree, sweetened condensed milk, and eggs.
Stir in cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg, cloves, and salt until well combined.
Pour the pumpkin mixture into the unbaked pie crust.
Bake at 425°F (220°C) for 15 minutes.
Reduce oven temperature to 350°F (175°C) and continue baking for 35-40 minutes, or until a knife inserted near the center comes out clean.
Let cool completely on a wire rack for at least 2 hours before slicing and serving. Serve chilled or at room temperature with whipped cream if desired.

staticRecipes.name: Roasted Pumpkin Seeds
staticRecipes.description: A crunchy and nutritious snack made from fresh pumpkin seeds.
ingredients: 1 tbsp olive oil or melted butter
Optional seasonings: garlic powder, paprika, cayenne pepper
steps: Preheat oven to 300°F (150°C).
Rinse pumpkin seeds thoroughly to remove all pulp and strings. Pat them very dry with paper towels (this is important for crispiness).
In a bowl, toss the dry seeds with olive oil/butter and salt. Add optional seasonings if desired.
Spread the seeds in a single layer on a baking sheet.
Roast for 20-30 minutes, stirring occasionally, until golden brown and crispy. Be careful not to burn them.
Let cool completely before eating. Store in an airtight container.

staticRecipes.name: Creamy Pumpkin Soup
staticRecipes.description: A smooth, savory, and warming soup perfect for fall.
ingredients: 1 (15 oz) can pumpkin puree (or 2 cups fresh cooked pumpkin)
1/2 cup heavy cream or coconut milk
1/2 tsp ground cinnamon or pumpkin pie spice
Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
Toasted pumpkin seeds or croutons for garnish (optional)
steps: Heat olive oil or butter in a large pot or Dutch oven over medium heat. Add chopped onion and cook until softened, about 5-7 minutes.
Add minced garlic and cook for 1 minute more until fragrant.
Stir in pumpkin puree, broth, and cinnamon/pumpkin pie spice. Bring to a simmer.
Reduce heat and cook for 10-15 minutes to allow flavors to meld.
Use an immersion blender to puree the soup until smooth. Alternatively, carefully transfer to a regular blender and blend in batches.
Stir in heavy cream or coconut milk. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Reheat gently if needed. Serve hot, garnished with toasted pumpkin seeds or croutons if desired.
